intro: Acaena stricta var. gracilis, commonly known as the slender burrplant, is a low-growing perennial herb native to New Zealand. It features dense clusters of small, spiny bracts that form the characteristic burrs, which are adapted for seed dispersal by attaching to animals. The plant has narrow, grass-like leaves and produces yellow flowers in early spring. It thrives in moist, well-drained soils and is often found in wetlands and along stream banks. Its unique morphology and ecological role make it an important species in its native habitat.
distribution_native_art_desc: Acaena stricta var. gracilis is primarily native to New Zealand. It is found in the southern and western regions of the country. This plant typically grows in coastal and subalpine areas. It is commonly associated with rocky and gravelly soils. Its distribution includes parts of the South Island and some areas of the North Island.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Acaena stricta var. gracilis was mainly introduced to New Zealand. It was brought there by European settlers during the 19th century. The plant was likely introduced as an ornamental species due to its attractive foliage and flowering. However, it has since become naturalized and is now considered a potential weed in some areas. Its distribution is primarily concentrated in the northern and central regions of New Zealand.
